S0021-9517(18)30468-8 10.1016/j.jcat.2018.11.027 Elsevier Inc. Fig. 1 Catalyst performance applying different conditions: (a) Different pyrolysis conditions of Zn/Co-ZIF, reaction conditions: 850 mg epichlorohydrin, 50 mg of catalysts, 140 °C, CO2 pressure 8 bars, 8 h. (b) Optimization of CO2 pressure and temperature using 35 mg Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000, and 850 mg of epichlorohydrin. Fig. 2 Catalyst recycling experiment: catalyst loading (left axis) and catalytic activity (right axis). Reaction conditions: 50 mg of Zn/Co-ZIF-H2Ar-1000 (5.88 %wt catalyst based on epichlorohydrin), 140 °C, 8 bars, 8 h, product analysis by 1H NMR. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIF at various temperatures. Fig. 4 SEM analysis of fresh Zn/Co-ZIF (a) and pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 (b); TEM analysis of Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 containing Co-particles and its diffraction pattern obtained in the insert picture (c), the carbon-wall matrix surrounding the metallic Co particles (d). Fig. 5 XPS characterization of the N and Co region of Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar: N 1 s (a) and Co 2p3/2 (b) spectra for Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar at 600 °C (bottom), 800 °C (middle), 1000 °C (top). Fig. 6 Mechanism for the CO2 addition to epoxide generating cyclic carbonates using Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000. Table 1 Various cyclic carbonates synthesized by using Zn/Co-ZIF-H2Ar-1000 as catalyst. Entry Epoxide Product Reaction time (h) Yield (%)* 1 8 93 2 8 70 3 14 72 4 15 74 * All the products obtained with 100% of selectivity. Robust and efficient catalyst derived from bimetallic Zn/Co zeolitic imidazolate frameworks for CO2 conversion Somboon Chaemchuen a b Xuan Xiao a c Marzieh Ghadamyari a c Bibimaryam Mousavi a Nikom Klomkliang d Ye Yuan a ⁎ Francis Verpoort a b c e ⁎ a Laboratory of Organometallics, Catalysis and Ordered Materials, State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, China Laboratory of Organometallics, Catalysis and Ordered Materials State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan China b National Research Tomsk Polytechnic University, Lenin Avenue 30, 634050 Tomsk, Russian Federation National Research Tomsk Polytechnic University Lenin Avenue 30 634050 Tomsk Russian Federation c School of Materials Science and Engineering, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan 430070, China School of Materials Science and Engineering Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan 430070 China d School of Chemical Engineering, Suranaree University of Technology, Nakhon Ratchasima 30000, Thailand School of Chemical Engineering Suranaree University of Technology Nakhon Ratchasima 30000 Thailand e College of Arts and Sciences, Khalifa University of Science and Technology, PO Box 127788, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates College of Arts and Sciences Khalifa University of Science and Technology PO Box 127788 Abu Dhabi United Arab Emirates ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Laboratory of Organometallics, Catalysis and Ordered Materials, State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing, Wuhan University of Technology, Wuhan, China (F. Verpoort). Laboratory of Organometallics, Catalysis and Ordered Materials State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing Wuhan University of Technology Wuhan China Graphical abstract A robust catalyst generated from the pyrolysis of bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF comprising magnetic properties demonstrated to be an effective heterogeneous catalyst system for CO2 conversion reaction without the need of co-catalyst and solvent. Controllable pyrolysis under various conditions resulted in a unique active structure composed of metallic particles stabilized in a nitrogen-doped carbon matrix. The metallic particles acting as acid sites are dispersed in a nitrogen-doped porous carbon-wall which provides the basic sites. These sites are created during the pyrolysis process of Zn/Co-ZIF used as a special template under a controlled atmosphere. The resulting material possessing both, acid and basic sites, showed an excellent catalytic performance for the cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxides as these sites correspond to the active sites in the catalytic cycle. Additional, the pyrolysis conditions indicated to play an important role in the properties of the resulting materials and in parallel with the catalytic performance. The catalytic material proved to be very robust and maintained high activities for at least eleven cycles using the optimized reaction condition. Moreover, the magnetic property of the resulting catalyst is advantageous especially for the separation from the reaction mixture. Keywords Bi-metallic ZIF Pyrolysis CO2 conversion Heterogeneous catalysis Cyclic carbonates 1 Introduction Utilization of carbon dioxide (CO2) as a carbon source has received extensive attention in research societies aiming to reduce CO2 emission which is the main cause of global warming [1,2]. Among the CO2 utilization reactions, the CO2 chemical fixation, producing carbonates is an economical attractive reaction pathway and remediates the environment of CO2 emission. Numerous cyclic carbonates are widely applied as electrolytes in Li-ion batteries, aprotic solvents for cosmetics, and intermediates in pharmaceutical and polymer synthesis, etc. [3,4]. Furthermore, several reports describe MOFs as efficient heterogeneous catalysts converting CO2 to value-added chemicals in absence of solvent and co-catalyst [5,6]. Tailoring the MOF structures via metals ions/clusters and specifically designed organic linkers provides advanced properties such as high CO2 uptake, permanent porosity, and active catalytic sites, etc. [7]. The Zn-based ZIFs (ZIF-8, ZIF-90, ZIF-68, etc.) were among the first MOFs to be applied as a catalyst for the conversion of CO2 with an epoxide to produce cyclic carbonates. However, these systems suffered from low selectivity and reusability [8,9]. Later on, Co-based MOFs were found to be active for this reaction as well, however, they exhibited lower conversion rates than their Zn-based MOF analogous. Recently, a bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF was developed via a simple synthesis method to synthesize a bimetallic MOF with Zn and Co as metal centers which showed enhanced gas adsorption properties [10,11]. Moreover, from all reported catalytic MOF materials, the bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF exhibited a high catalytic conversion of epoxide to carbonates using CO2 as a C1 source with excellent selectivity and performance [10]. Nevertheless, MOFs applied as heterogeneous catalysts possess a relatively low chemical/thermal stability and combined with their small particle size, these drawbacks have to be considered for large-scale or industrial applications. Moreover, small particle-sized catalysts may require complicated purification procedures for the separation from the reaction mixture. Therefore, the exploration of new pathways making the catalytic material stable and comprising magnetic properties could be an attractive route to develop a catalyst for e.g. the CO2 addition reaction. The ability to manufacture MOFs/ZIFs on large scale with high purity at a low price is still challenging and prevent the transfer of these materials into implementation [12]. The commercial application requires a strong imperative to develop and produce efficiently with versatile means MOFs at large scale. In this sense, we recently reported that the spray drying method could be used to synthesize ZIFs having a uniform structure and unique properties [13–15]. Especially, using the spray-drying synthesis method MOFs with remarkably attractive properties for catalytic application were generated [15]. Recently, metallic particles dispersed in a carbon matrix synthesized via carbonization/pyrolysis of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been intensively investigated. These techniques use MOFs as a template and proceed under a certain atmosphere and high temperature to obtain the desired material. The framework of the MOF collapses at these conditions, due to the decomposition of the organic linker which is partially or completely pyrolyzed (converted into a carbon matrix). Additionally, the metal ions/clusters become mobile within the matrix and metal species are created or the metal even evaporates [16]. The various applied conditions result in different types of materials with diverse properties. These materials attracted numerous attentions for several applications, especially for high-performance electronic devices such as batteries, capacitors, etc. [17,18] due to their structure made of a carbon matrix and metal species deriving from MOFs applied as a template. Excellent electronic connections between the metallic/metal oxide and carbon matrix were provided [19]. While catalytic reactions, as a heterogeneous application of metals doped in a carbon matrix, are still explored rarely. A hierarchical carbon matrix is usually generated during the pyrolysis of the original MOF material by volatilization at high temperature, together with highly dispersed metal nanoparticles encapsulated within the porous carbon matrix. Nonetheless, the main hurdle in the development of these materials is tailoring the porosity and morphology of carbonaceous nanostructures when a metal phase remains in the resulting carbon material [20]. In this study, we investigated metal nanoparticles encapsulated in a nitrogen-doped porous carbon material deriving from the pyrolysis of bimetallic MOFs (Zn/Co-ZIF) used as a template under various controllable pyrolysis conditions. The bimetallic MOF, Zn/Co-ZIF, was selected for this investigation since the Zn/Co-ZIF itself (not-pyrolyzed) demonstrated a better CO2 fixation performance compared with the single-metal ZIFs (ZIF-8, ZIF-67) as reported before by our group [15]. The synthesis of the bimetallic MOF was done using a spray drying procedure. The spray drying technique was applied to provide a synthesis method suitable for making materials for large-scale productions. The final metal nanoparticles encapsulated in a nitrogen-doped porous carbon material was applied as a heterogeneous catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxide producing carbonate compounds without co-catalyst, and solvent-free. Furthermore, taking advantage of the magnetic properties of carbon material, separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture is straightforward and beneficial for the recycling of the catalyst. 2 Experimental All reagents were purchased from Aladdin chemical and used as received without any further purification. The template material (Zn/Co-ZIF) was synthesized using spray dry equipment (AF−88 laboratory spray dryer, AFIND Scientific Instrument CO. Ltd.). Two solutions of Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (3 mmol), Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (3 mmol) in water (25 mL) and 2-methylimidazole (0.66 g, 8 mmol) in water (25 mL) were mixed as a feed solution. The obtained suspension was then used as the feed for the spray dryer having an 8 mm diameter spray nozzle, at a feed rate of 400 mL/h, with a flow rate of 160 m3/h and an inlet temperature of 180 °C. The powder product was collected and immersed in methanol for a certain time for the re-crystallization process. Finally, the suspension was separated, washed with methanol and dried at room temperature under vacuum for 12 h. Thereafter, the temperature was raised to 120 °C for 3 h under vacuum. The dried material was heated (pyrolyzed) to the required temperature with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min applying different gas atmospheres (flow rate 50 cc/min) for 4 h. Thereafter, the material was transferred to a desiccator to cool down to room temperature. The material was kept in the desiccator and was used for further analysis and utilization. The catalytic reactions were performed as previously reported with only a minor modification; 9 mmol of epoxide (substrate) and 50 mg of pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIFs were charged in a 10 mL stainless steel high-pressure reactor (XINGDA company, Beijing, China) [21]. The catalyst was dispersed on the bottom of the reactor. No magnetic stir bar was added to prevent the accumulation of catalyst on the magnetic stir bar since the catalyst is magnetic. The substrate (epoxide) was added before purging the system with CO2 gas for a few minutes. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was pressurized with CO2 (99.9%) and kept at the required pressure using a pressure regulator. After the required reaction time at the required conditions, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature followed by venting the excess of gas. The final product was analyzed by 1H NMR. The catalyst was magnetically separated from the reaction mixture and washed several times with methanol followed by drying under vacuum at 80 °C for 6 h before the next use (details are available in the ESI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity Among the MOFs, the zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) have been mostly used as precursors or MOF template to develop porous carbon material. Recently, bimetallic metal-organic frameworks (BMOFs) have been developed as precursor possessing two types of integrated metal ions with properties depending on the ratio of the metal ions [22,23]. The characteristic properties of the spray dried Zn/Co-ZIF material indicated a successful formation of a homogeneous structure similar to previous reports [10,24]. The Zn/Co-ZIF structure is isoreticular possessing unit cell parameters similar to ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 as determined by powder-XRD (Fig. 1, in Data in Brief). Properties such as the morphology (SEM), surface area and porosity (N2 adsorption at 77 K), the chemical coordination (FT-IR), the thermal stability (TGA), etc. were determined (Figs. 1–5, in Data in Brief). After verifying the Zn/Co-ZIF structure, the material was pyrolyzed applying various atmospheres and temperatures (denoted as Zn/Co-ZIF-X-Y wherein X = Ar, H2/Ar or Air, and Y = pyrolysis temperature in °C). For Zn/Co-ZIF, pyrolysis at a temperature higher than 600 °C a black colored material encapsulating metallic nanoparticles was obtained. The CO2 fixation with an epoxide to produce cyclic carbonate was selected as a green atom efficient reaction, besides, Zn/Co-ZIF was reported to demonstrate the best catalytic performance among all MOFs families for this fixation reaction [10,25]. Additionally, the spray-dry method, a fast synthesis and convenient method to produce Zn/Co-ZIF, was explored over other synthesis routes [10]. Epichlorohydrin as substrate was used to optimize the reaction conditions and investigate the influence of pyrolysis conditions of Zn/Co-ZIF. The catalytic performance of the different Zn/Co-ZIF-X-Y materials was analyzed via 1H NMR (calculation details are available in supporting information). To have a reference, the initial Zn/Co-ZIF (non-pyrolyzed) was firstly examined for the chemical fixation of CO2 (Table 1, in Data in Brief, entry 3–5). The product yield can raise up > 99% by increasing the reaction temperature (Table 1, in Data in Brief, entry 5), while the selectivity still remains 100% for non-pyrolysis Zn/Co-ZIF prepared via the spray drying method. Pyrolyzed materials obtained via calcination in air (presence of oxygen; Zn/Co-ZIF-Air) exhibit a drop in the catalytic performance, which can be explained by the decomposition of the ZIF structure at higher calcination temperature (for more details see material characterizations and discussion). A contradictory behavior of the catalytic performance was observed after pyrolysis of Zn/Co-ZIF under inert gas (Ar) and even more improved under a reducing atmosphere (5% H2/Ar) as shown in Fig. 1 a. Thereafter, the optimum pyrolysis conditions were applied to prepare the catalytic material (Zn/Co-ZIF-H2Ar-1000). This material was then used to investigate the ideal reaction conditions such as catalyst loading, reaction temperature, and pressure, etc. Increasing the catalyst loading, while keeping other parameters constant, an improvement was observed and a 93% yield was obtained using 50 mg catalyst (Fig. 6, in Data in Brief). Next, the reaction time was investigated and an increased yield, up to 93% was demonstrated for a prolonged reaction time of 8 h (Table 1, in Data in Brief, entry 6–9). It is well known that the reaction temperature and pressure play crucial roles in the CO2 addition reaction. The catalytic performance improves with higher temperature, while the catalytic activity remains stable at a certain pressure (Fig. 1 b). Additionally, it has to be mentioned that an excellent selectivity (100%) was obtained using the pyrolyzed material (Zn/Co-ZIF- H2Ar-1000). To verify the unique catalytic properties of the material deriving from pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIF, a series of carbon materials and pyrolyzed metal-precursor (Co, Zn-acetate) were investigated, see Table 1, in Data in Brief, entry 7–15. It is clear that materials not deriving from pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIF exhibited a very low catalytic performance, although, some materials showed some activity compared to the blank test (no-catalyst) Table 1, in Data in Brief. Carbon nanotube as a catalyst revealed 20.8% yield, while carbon graphite only gives 10% yield. These results may suggest that the porosity of the carbon species plays a role in the catalytic performance. Moreover, incorporated metal impurities in the carbon species could provide some activity as well [26,27]. Surprisingly, pyrolyzed Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O using similar conditions as for Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 was inactive. Zn species (zinc oxide and carbonate) including pyrolyzed Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O were evaluated as well on their catalytic performance for the CO2 addition (Table 1, in Data in Brief, entry 13–15). The obtained results clearly indicate that the catalyst Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 obtained from pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIF is of utmost importance to determine the catalytic performance for the CO2 fixation with an epoxide. Finally, treatment of Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 with an acid to etch out unstable Co particles and/or CoO from the pyrolyzed product as previously reported for electrochemical catalysts was also investigated [28,29]. However, a reduced or no activity was obtained (Table 1, in Data in Brief, entry 16 and 17) suggesting an undesirable change of the metallic Co particles to un-active species during the etching process. The substrate scope was studied by using different epoxides in combination with the Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 catalyst (Table 1 ). All the epoxides were converted into cyclic carbonates without the need for solvent and co-catalyst. Although, for epoxides different than epichlorohydrin the obtained yields were lower indicating that for each substrate the reaction conditions could be further optimized. Besides the metal nanoparticles present in the N-doped carbon matrix, another very attractive characteristic of Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 catalyst is its magnetic property. Due to the presence of Co nanoparticles, this catalyst system could be easily separated from the reaction mixture and reused several times without any significant loss in catalytic efficiency. The recyclability of Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-1000 was investigated using epichlorohydrin under 8 bar of CO2 pressure and 140 °C for 8 h. Thanks to the magnetic characteristics of the catalyst the catalyst could easily be separated from the reaction mixture using a magnet. The spent catalyst was washed several times with methanol followed by drying at 80 °C under vacuum for 6 h. The catalyst could catalyze the reaction without any significant reduction in catalytic performance and material weight for at least 11 recycles times. The XRD characterization of the recycled catalyst revealed that the composition remains the same as the fresh catalyst (Fig. 12, in Data in Brief). These results demonstrate and confirm that the catalyst can be easily separated and reused. 3.2 Material characterization To find out more about the diverse catalytic behavior of the novel materials obtained via pyrolysis, XRD analyses were performed. Different crystal patterns of the pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIF were observed depending on the pyrolysis conditions (atmosphere and temperature) as displayed in Fig. 3 and Fig. 11, in Data in Brief. Generally, for Zn/Co-ZIF pyrolyzed under inert atmosphere, the organic linker (2-methylimidazole) is converted into carbon and nitrogen compounds while the metal ions (Zn and Co) are reduced to metallic Co and Zn covered with an N-doped carbon matrix [30]. When Zn/Co-ZIF is pyrolyzed in the presence of air then the MOF structure decomposes at a temperature higher then 400 °C and metal oxide is generated (Fig. 11a, in Data in Brief). These results are in excellent agreement with the reported thermal stability of Zn/Co-ZIF, the MOF structure was retained up to 400–500 °C under an inert atmosphere and lower in the presence of oxygen [10]. At higher calcination temperature (>400 °C) metal oxide with ashes are produced resulting in a loss of the catalytic performance for the fixation reaction since metal oxide is not the active catalyst as proven with results in Table 1, in Data in Brief, entry 12–14). While under an inert (Ar) and 5% H2/Ar atmosphere metallic and/or metal oxide crystals were produced as shown in Fig. 3. Furthermore, Zn and Co nanoparticles might remain in the N-doped carbon matrix until a certain pyrolysis temperature, though, at a high temperature (1000 °C) zinc is eliminated, as shown in Fig. 11b, and c, in Data in Brief. At a temperature of 1000 °C, the metallic zinc evaporates as the boiling point of metallic zinc is 908 °C and the lack of zinc was also confirmed with metal element analysis (ICP, Table 2, in Data in Brief) [18]. The temperature also affects the diffraction line at 44.2°, which is assigned to the Co metallic species with a face-centered cubic (fcc, Fm3m(2 2 5), a = 0.355 nm) structure (JCPDS no. 15–0806). The diffraction line becomes more and more intense with an increasing temperature, suggesting an elevation of the crystallinity degree of the metallic Co species in the N-doped carbon matrix. That the metallic Co species are enclosed in carbon layers was also confirmed via TEM analysis [22]. The XRD analysis revealed the importance of atmospheric conditions and temperature during the pyrolysis to provide metal nanoparticles in an N-doped carbon matrix. A reducing atmosphere could promote the metallic dispersion in an N-doped carbon matrix. Moreover, it was reported recently that using reducing conditions (H2/Ar) during pyrolysis, ZIF-67 particles played a critical role in the formation of N-doped carbon nanotube frameworks (NCNTFs) by favoring the formation of metallic Co nanoparticles and also catalyzing the growth of hierarchical shells of interconnected crystalline NCNTs [31]. Moreover, the resultant NCNTFs retained the size and morphology of the initial ZIF-67 particles while possessing hierarchical shells of interconnected crystalline NCNTs. Therefore, in this study, the morphologies of Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar obtained at elevated temperature from 600° to 1000 °C were investigated using a scanning electron microscope (SEM). The pyrolyzed materials partially shrink and deform and smaller particle size in line with the pyrolysis temperature are observed (Fig. 13, in Data in Brief). Similar bumpy morphologies of materials pyrolyzed under Ar with shrinkage of particle size were reported [22]. Furthermore, the size and volume are smaller than their parent Zn/Co-ZIF and smaller than products obtained at higher pyrolysis temperature that suggested that shrinking of particles occurs during pyrolysis. The Co species agglomerate together forming metallic nanoparticles in an N-doped carbon matrix as confirmed by TEM and element mapping (EDS) measurements (Fig. 4 and Fig. 14, in Data in Brief). The Co nanoparticles size ranges from 5 nm up to 50 nm and is closely wrapped by several carbon layers and uniformly distributed in the porous carbon phase (Fig. 4c). The representative TEM image shows the Co particles enclosed in the microporous carbon layers (arrow pointing in Fig. 4d). The spatial distribution of carbon, nitrogen, and cobalt was detected by elemental mapping (Fig. 14, in Data in Brief). Especially, the spatial confinement of the element species is particularly important for suppressing the dissolution and aggregation of the metal nanoparticles, which is advantageous for maintaining a high stability under working conditions. The surface area and porosity analysis by N2 adsorption-desorption at −196 °C revealed an enormous reduction after pyrolysis (Table 2 and Fig. 15, in Data in Brief). These results correspond directly to the decomposition of the template framework of Zn/Co-ZIF. The obtained porous carbon material possesses pores spanning from the micro- to the macro range and are in good agreement with the previous observation of MOFs pyrolysis [32]. The isotherms show sharp uptakes at relatively low pressure (P/P0  < 0.05) which is typical for Type I isotherm of a microporous material. Furthermore, the presence of a hysteresis loop at high relative pressure (P/P0  > 0.9) is typical for a type IV isotherm and is most probably due to the removal of metal oxide/metal species from the template. This indicates that the pyrolyzed materials are totally microporous materials with some macropores probably due to particle aggregation (i.e. interparticle void) [33]. Obviously, careful investigation clarified that the lower surface area is caused by the loss of porosity (pore volume; Pv and/or pore size; Ps) as a consequence of the framework collapse and decomposition during the pyrolysis process. Especially, the enormous decrease in porosity down to non-porosity was obtained at a higher pyrolysis temperature in the presence of oxygen (Air). Interestingly, the results illustrate a small increase in surface area when pyrolyzed under Ar and H2/Ar at temperatures ranging from 600 °C to 800 °C which corresponds to a higher porosity (Pv and Ps). Additionally, according to the thermal stability of the metals, Zn metal can be partially eliminated at high temperatures which is in agreement with the intensity decline of the Zn XRD diffraction line. Unfortunately, the surface area of these pyrolyzed materials reduces slightly at the highest temperature (1000 °C) under Ar and H2/Ar atmosphere which is the result of the evaporation of Zn from the frameworks, as confirmed by the Zn element analysis (ICP) shown in Table 2, in Data in Brief. Surprisingly, the carbonaceous materials demonstrate clearly a higher adsorption of carbon dioxide (CO2) in comparison with the template material (Zn/Co-ZIF). Furthermore, these results provide the possibility to use these materials in more and different CO2 adsorption applications since the development of innovations for CO2 capture has been considered an urgent task on the way toward a sustainable low-carbon future. To gain further insight regarding the type of metal species and nitrogen species present in the Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar materials, XPS characterization was performed (Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar was selected due to its attractive catalytic performance). Three types of N were observed in the N 1s spectrum having electron binding energies of 398.8, 400.5, and 401.6 eV, which are attributed to pyridine-type, pyrrole-type, and ammonium-type nitrogen species, respectively (Fig. 5) [34]. The highest percentage of pyridinic nitrogen was obtained using the lowest pyrolysis temperature (Zn/Co-ZIF-H2/Ar-600). This amount reduced at a higher pyrolysis temperature, contrarily, pyrrole-type, and ammonium-type N-species increased at a higher temperature. Additionally, Jaouen et al. reported N-species at 399–400.5 eV (pyrrole) resulting from nitrogen bonded to metal [35], of which the amount increased at higher pyrolysis temperature and might play a role in the catalytic activity. Also, the elimination of the zinc metal at higher pyrolysis temperature could further promoted the pyrrole-type nitrogen in the pyrolyzed material. Moreover, these coordination interactions are advantageous in preventing aggregation of Co species in the course of the pyrolysis process, and it is in good agreement with the TEM observations (Fig. 4d). A different chemical Co environment was observed as well, depending on the pyrolysis temperature, see Fig. 5b. Co0 at 778.3 eV and CoII at 780.6 eV are both present in the sample obtained at 800 °C. Whereas, at a temperature of 1000 °C a higher contribution of divalent Co0 (778.3 eV) is observed. The observation suggests that there are interactions between the Co species with nitrogen or carbon matrix and probably is the key to facilitate the formation of uniformly dispersed Co particles. The above results demonstrate that the N-doping could promote the basic properties of the material and play an important role in the dispersion of Co species, which may lead to materials with excellent catalytic performances. Remarkably as well is that both the basicity and acidity play a crucial role in the catalytic performance of CO2 addition into epoxide generating cyclic carbonate similar as previously reported for this reaction [25,36,37]. Herein, the metal species (Co and/or Zn) present in the pyrolyzed materials was confirmed from characterizations such as XRD, XPS etc. The basicity present on pyrolyzed Zn/Co-ZIF materials was elucidated by CO2-TPD (Fig. 17, in Data in Brief) using a similar approach as reported recently for pyrolyzed ZIF-67 [23]. Furthermore, these analyses reveal that pyrolyzed MOFs with N-containing ligands such as ZIFs could enhance the basicity of the resulting materials. The N-species of uncoordinated metal sites (pyrrole-type) generated during the metal elimination in the pyrolysis process at high temperature promote the catalytic performance as a basic site. Moreover, the increased CO2 adsorption at 0 °C also confirmed the presence of a higher amount of basic sites in pyrolyzed materials. The acidity of the synthesized material was determined by ammonia temperature programmed desorption analysis (NH3-TPD) as displayed in Fig. 18, in Data in Brief. Strong interactions of acid sites were mainly observed at high desorption temperature (500–700 °C), while a small broad band within the temperature range of 200–350 °C was attributed to the weak adsorption of NH3 molecules. Additionally, Li et al. have reported that the uniform dispersion of Co species is promoted by the introduction of N-containing ligands using pyrolysis of the Co-MOF (Co9(btc)6(tpt)2(H2O)15). This uniform distribution plays a key role to obtain an excellent catalytic performance in the oxidation reaction of alcohols [23]. The above characterization results revealed that pyrolysis of Zn/Co-ZIF having N-containing linkers exhibits well-dispersed Co in an N-doped porous carbon matrix, which promotes the basic and acid properties of the material and hence, play a role in the catalytic performance. Consequently, the reaction mechanism for the CO2 cycloaddition using cobalt in an N-doped carbon matrix as a heterogeneous catalyst can be attributed to the presence of basic sites deriving from N-compounds (N-doped carbon matrix) activating the carbon-oxygen bond of CO2, while Lewis acid sites originating from Co species activate the ring opening of the epoxide (Fig. 6). Moreover, the existence of well-dispersed Co species surrounded by a protecting carbon-wall could favor the binding and activation of the epoxide (substrate). Hence, the basicity deriving from the N-compounds not only activates the carbon dioxide but also enhances its adsorption and thus promotes the catalytic reaction. Moreover, the carbon wall/layer surrounding the metallic particles could prevent aggregation and leaching of metal species during the catalytic reaction. The results reveal that the pyrolysis conditions play a key role in the material properties which are of crucial importance for the catalytic performance. The metal oxides in the ash content were obtained after pyrolysis under air (calcination in the presence of oxygen) demonstrated to be inactive due to the lack of acid/basic sites required for this catalytic reaction. Moreover, the disappearance of the carbon matrix and the large weight loss was observed after pyrolysis in the air as well. The metallic and/or metal oxide particles in the carbon matrix with doped N-species obtained after pyrolysis under inert atmosphere proofed to be catalytic active as a result of the presence of acid-sites (metal species) and basic-site (N-doped carbon species). The materials pyrolyzed under a reducing atmosphere (5% H2/Ar) exhibited the best catalytic performance compared to the samples obtained under a non-reducing atmosphere. Moreover, applying a higher pyrolysis temperature combined with a reducing atmosphere further enhanced the catalytic performance. The higher catalytic activity is related to the increasing number of pyrrole-type N-species (basic sites) obtained at high pyrolysis temperature resulting from the metal elimination (Zn) at this high temperature. The dispersed metallic particles (Co-particles) interacting with the carbon matrix (confirmed from XPS) promote the acid sites required for the catalytic reaction and prevent metal leaching from the carbon matrix. Therefore, dual catalytic active sites (acid/basic) were created in a unique structure of which the properties derived from a controlled pyrolysis process of a bi-metallic ZIF. 4 Conclusion A robust catalyst made of metal nanoparticles in an N-doped carbon matrix deriving from controllable pyrolysis of bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF as a template was utilized as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst for the CO2 conversion reaction. The pyrolysis process of bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF template attributed to the decomposition of the ZIF framework and vaporization of gaseous species during pyrolysis creating metallic nanoparticles in an N-doped carbon matrix. The temperature and atmosphere during the pyrolysis process were the main parameters affecting the creation of a unique structure and properties of the pyrolyzed material. The characterization of the catalyst pointed out that the Co species hybrid with N species in the composite carbon matrix wall improving the metal dispersion and catalytic properties. The dual sites, acids (Co) and basics (N-based) were generated and work parallel as active sites for the catalytic reaction. The advantage of a stable and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst was investigated and an excellent catalytic performance without the use of co-catalyst and solvent was obtained. Furthermore, the catalyst could be easily separated and recycled by using an external magnetic field. The present facile-to-prepare catalyst material might provide a simple, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly alternative for the catalyzed addition of CO2 to epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: A robust catalyst generated from the pyrolysis of bimetallic Zn/Co-ZIF comprising magnetic properties demonstrated to be an effective heterogeneous catalyst system for CO2 conversion reaction without the need of co-catalyst and solvent. Controllable pyrolysis under various conditions resulted in a unique active structure composed of metallic particles stabilized in a nitrogen-doped carbon matrix. The metallic particles acting as acid sites are dispersed in a nitrogen-doped porous carbon-wall which provides the basic sites. These sites are created during the pyrolysis process of Zn/Co-ZIF used as a special template under a controlled atmosphere. The resulting material possessing both, acid and basic sites, showed an excellent catalytic performance for the cycloaddition of CO2 into epoxides as these sites correspond to the active sites in the catalytic cycle. Additional, the pyrolysis conditions indicated to play an important role in the properties of the resulting materials and in parallel with the catalytic performance. The catalytic material proved to be very robust and maintained high activities for at least eleven cycles using the optimized reaction condition. Moreover, the magnetic property of the resulting catalyst is advantageous especially for the separation from the reaction mixture.
coredata.dc:title: Robust and efficient catalyst derived from bimetallic Zn/Co zeolitic imidazolate frameworks for CO2 conversion
